heading: rare peek at mercury
subheading: look, up in the sky! it's a bird! it's a plane! no, it's mercury streaking across the sun. and well-equipped earthlings get the rare chance to observe the tiny planet.
author: wired news report
text: if you're strolling outside monday afternoon, and you just happen to be wielding a telescope with suitable solar filters, you might notice a black dot sliding across the sun. don't be alarmed. it's only the planet mercury doing what it does about 13 times a century –- making a pass across the disc of the sun.on monday at 3:15 p.m. est, mercury will appear in the form of a black disk at "the sun's northern limb, about a third of the way around from north to east," according to nasa.it is mercury's first trek across the disk of the sun since 1993 and it'll be its last until the year 2003.nasa officials caution observers to never look directly at the sun, but instead to use eyepiece projection or solar filters.
